paper_title: Synthesis of hierarchical flower-like Bi<sub>2</sub>MoO<sub>6</sub>microspheres as efficient photocatalyst for photoreduction of CO<sub>2</sub>into solar fuels under visible light

catalyst.source: This demonstrates that the hierarchical flower-like Bi 2 MoO 6 is a simple, efficient and promising visible-light-driven photocatalyst for the photoreduction of CO 2 into solar fuels.
catalyst.context: Hierarchical flower-like Bi 2 MoO 6 microspheres were successfully synthesized via a facile hydrothermal approach, employing PVP as the crystal growth modifier.The building units of the hierarchical flower-like Bi 2 MoO 6 were constructed by two-dimensional thin flakes, which intercrossed with each other and aggregated together to form the three-dimensional flower-like structure.The PVP amount and hydrothermal duration played crucial roles in the formation of the Bi 2 MoO 6 architectures with evolving morphologies.The Bi 2 MoO 6 samples were first evaluated for the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 into methanol and ethanol as solar fuels under visible-light irradiation.It has been found that the hierarchical flower-like Bi 2 MoO 6 exhibits highly efficient photocatalytic activity.After 4 hours of irradiation, the yields of methanol and ethanol were 24.8 and 18.8 mol g cat -1 respectively, higher than those obtained over previously-reported Bi 2 WO 6 hollow microspheres.This demonstrates that the hierarchical flower-like Bi 2 MoO 6 is a simple, efficient and promising visible-light-driven photocatalyst for the photoreduction of CO 2 into solar fuels.

catalyst.source: Electrochemical measurements were carried out on an electrochemical analyzer (CHI 660D Instruments) in a standard three-electrode system, with the synthesized Bi 2 MoO 6 samples as the working electrodes with an active area of catalyst of 1.0 cm 2 , graphite as the counter electrode and a SCE (saturated calomel electrode) as a reference electrode.
catalyst.context: All the reagents were analytical grade and used without further purification.Hierarchical flower-like Bi 2 MoO 6 microspheres were synthesized by the following procedure: 1.94 g Bi(NO 3 ) 3 5H 2 O, 0.484 g Na 2 MoO 4 2H 2 O and 0.3 g PVP were each dissolved in 20 mL of 1 M HNO 3 solution to obtain solutions A, B and C, respectively.Then, solutions B and C were added into solution A under vigorous stirring to obtain a suspension.After an additional agitation for 30 min at room temperature, the as-obtained colloidal suspension was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 180 C for 24 h.After that, the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature naturally.The precipitate was collected by centrifugation, washed with distilled water and absolute ethanol several times, and dried at 80 C under ambient air for 12 h. For the mechanistic study, different sets of hydrothermal reactions carried out for different time intervals (0, 1, 6, 12, 24 and 36 h) and using different PVP amounts (0, 0.05, 0.1, 0.2 and 0.3 g), using identical reaction conditions, were set up for the synthesis of Bi 2 MoO 6 . The X-ray diffraction (XRD) of powder samples was examined using a Bruker AXS-D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer with Cu K radiation in the 2 range of 10-70.Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) was carried out on a Nova NanoSEM 450 microscope.Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) was obtained with the INCA 250 accessory of the Nova NanoSEM 450.Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) observations were performed on a JEOL JEM-2100 TEM.UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) were recorded using a Hitachi U-3900H UV-vis spectrophotometer using an integrating sphere accessory.The photoluminescence (PL) spectra were measured at room temperature using a Hitachi F4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Electrochemical measurements were carried out on an electrochemical analyzer (CHI 660D Instruments) in a standard three-electrode system, with the synthesized Bi 2 MoO 6 samples as the working electrodes with an active area of catalyst of 1.0 cm 2 , graphite as the counter electrode and a SCE (saturated calomel electrode) as a reference electrode.The Mott-Schottky measurement was performed at a fixed frequency of 1000 Hz with 5 mV amplitude.As for the photocurrent measurements, a 300 W Xe lamp equipped with an ultraviolet cut-off filter to provide visible light ( 420 nm) served as the visible light source.A 0.5 M Na 2 SO 4 aqueous solution was used as the electrolyte. 50 mg of Bi 2 MoO 6 powder were suspended in 50 mL of deionized water under stirring in a closed vessel at 4 C.A 300 W Xe arc lamp (PLS-SXE300) equipped with an ultraviolet cutoff filter to provide visible light ( 420 nm) was used as the light source.Prior to irradiation, the above suspension was thoroughly degassed to remove air, and high purity CO 2 gas (99.995) was bubbled into the solution for 30 min to expel dissolved oxygen in the reaction system.After beginning irradiation, 2 mL of suspension were sampled at certain time intervals and centrifuged to remove the photocatalyst particles.The products were qualitatively analyzed by an Agilent Technologies 7890A gas chromatograph (FID detector, DB-WAX column) through observing and comparing the chromatographic peaks with those for the authentic methanol and ethanol standard.During the whole photoreduction process, CO 2 gas was continuously bubbled through the solution at a rate of 50 mL min -1 .According to further analysis, the atomic molar ratio of Bi : Mo is approximately 2.1 : 1, which is close to the stoichiometric proportion of Bi 2 MoO 6 (2 : 1).Furthermore, the excess oxygen, as well as the carbon and nitrogen in the examined as-prepared catalysts, possibly originated from an organic contaminant and/or residual PVP.

catalyst.context: Structure and morphology characterizationHierarchical flower-like Bi 2 MoO 6 microspheres (denoted as BM-HFMS) were directly synthesized by hydrothermal treatment for 24 h with 0.3 g of PVP as the crystal growth modifier.The crystalline phase and purity of the BM-HFMS was analyzed by XRD.It can be seen that all the sharp reflection peaks in the XRD pattern (Fig.1a) can be indexed as the pure orthorhombic phase of Bi 2 MoO 6 , with lattice constants of a 5.506 A, b 16.226A and c 5.487 A, consistent with the standard values (JCPDS file card No. 72-1524).No peaks of any other phases or impurities were detected in this pattern.Additionally, an EDS analysis was carried out to further investigate the composition of the BM-HFMS.The EDS result, shown in Fig. 1b, reveals the obvious signals of O, Bi and Mo elements. Hierarchical flower-like Bi 2 MoO 6 microstructures built by intercrossed two-dimensional thin flakes were successfully synthesized by a facile and economical method, with the assistance of PVP.The formation mechanism and the effects of the PVP amount and hydrothermal time were investigated in detail.It is believed that the crystal anisotropy and the faceinhibitor function of PVP play important roles during the crystal growth of the hierarchical flower-like microstructures.The resulting hierarchical flower-like Bi 2 MoO 6 crystals show good photoabsorption performance, separation efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pairs and photocatalytic activity for the photoreduction of CO 2 into methanol and ethanol under visible-light irradiation.It is noted that the fabricated flower-like Bi 2 MoO 6 exhibits superior photocatalytic activity over Bi 2 MoO 6 nanoparticles and nanoplates, as well as Bi 2 WO 6 hollow microspheres.This work demonstrates that Fig. 11 Mott-Schottky plot of the hierarchical flower-like Bi 2 MoO 6 microspheres. Electrochemical measurements were carried out on an electrochemical analyzer (CHI 660D Instruments) in a standard three-electrode system, with the synthesized Bi 2 MoO 6 samples as the working electrodes with an active area of catalyst of 1.0 cm 2 , graphite as the counter electrode and a SCE (saturated calomel electrode) as a reference electrode.The Mott-Schottky measurement was performed at a fixed frequency of 1000 Hz with 5 mV amplitude.As for the photocurrent measurements, a 300 W Xe lamp equipped with an ultraviolet cut-off filter to provide visible light ( 420 nm) served as the visible light source.A 0.5 M Na 2 SO 4 aqueous solution was used as the electrolyte. 50 mg of Bi 2 MoO 6 powder were suspended in 50 mL of deionized water under stirring in a closed vessel at 4 C.A 300 W Xe arc lamp (PLS-SXE300) equipped with an ultraviolet cutoff filter to provide visible light ( 420 nm) was used as the light source.Prior to irradiation, the above suspension was thoroughly degassed to remove air, and high purity CO 2 gas (99.995) was bubbled into the solution for 30 min to expel dissolved oxygen in the reaction system.After beginning irradiation, 2 mL of suspension were sampled at certain time intervals and centrifuged to remove the photocatalyst particles.The products were qualitatively analyzed by an Agilent Technologies 7890A gas chromatograph (FID detector, DB-WAX column) through observing and comparing the chromatographic peaks with those for the authentic methanol and ethanol standard.During the whole photoreduction process, CO 2 gas was continuously bubbled through the solution at a rate of 50 mL min -1 .According to further analysis, the atomic molar ratio of Bi : Mo is approximately 2.1 : 1, which is close to the stoichiometric proportion of Bi 2 MoO 6 (2 : 1).Furthermore, the excess oxygen, as well as the carbon and nitrogen in the examined as-prepared catalysts, possibly originated from an organic contaminant and/or residual PVP.

reaction medium.context: All the reagents were analytical grade and used without further purification.Hierarchical flower-like Bi 2 MoO 6 microspheres were synthesized by the following procedure: 1.94 g Bi(NO 3 ) 3 5H 2 O, 0.484 g Na 2 MoO 4 2H 2 O and 0.3 g PVP were each dissolved in 20 mL of 1 M HNO 3 solution to obtain solutions A, B and C, respectively.Then, solutions B and C were added into solution A under vigorous stirring to obtain a suspension.After an additional agitation for 30 min at room temperature, the as-obtained colloidal suspension was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 180 C for 24 h.After that, the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature naturally.The precipitate was collected by centrifugation, washed with distilled water and absolute ethanol several times, and dried at 80 C under ambient air for 12 h.
